articles.headline: All Eyes on China as U.S. Signals New Tack on North Korea
articles.snippet: As Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson heads to Beijing, his interactions with his hosts, and whether he takes a hard line with China over its support for North Korea, will be closely watched.
articles.abstract: As Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson heads to Beijing, his interactions with his hosts, and whether he takes a hard line with China over its support for North Korea, will be closely watched.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson signaled on Friday that the Trump administration was prepared to scrap nearly a decade of United States policy toward North Korea in favor of a more aggressive effort to eliminate the country’s nuclear weapons program. Whether that means pre-emptive action, which he warned was “on the table,” will depend a great deal on how China responds.

articles.headline: Betsy DeVos’s Hiring of For-Profit College Official Raises Impartiality Issues
articles.snippet: Robert S. Eitel, a lawyer for a for-profit college operator under repeated scrutiny, has taken an Education Department post while on unpaid leave.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Eitel, a lawyer for a for-profit college operator under repeated scrutiny, has taken an Education Department post while on unpaid leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: As chief compliance officer for a corporate owner of for-profit colleges, Robert S. Eitel spent the past 18 months as a top lawyer for a company facing multiple government investigations, including one that ended with a settlement of more than $30 million over deceptive student lending.

articles.headline: How ‘Consumer Relief’ After Mortgage Crisis Can Enrich Big Banks
articles.snippet: In their settlements with the government, large financial institutions can actually earn money while also helping homeowners.
articles.abstract: In their settlements with the government, large financial institutions can actually earn money while also helping homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: In every multibillion dollar settlement with a big bank that peddled faulty mortgage securities, a major provision has been a requirement that the bank provide “consumer relief.”

articles.headline: One Billion Yahoo Accounts Still for Sale, Despite Hacking Indictments
articles.snippet: Federal investigators continue to pursue the people behind a 2013 attack compromising user accounts, despite filing charges in a 2014 cyberattack.
articles.abstract: Federal investigators continue to pursue the people behind a 2013 attack compromising user accounts, despite filing charges in a 2014 cyberattack.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For sale: one billion Yahoo accounts, $200,000 or best offer. The passwords don’t work, but the dates of birth, telephone numbers and security questions could still be useful to an adept cyberthief.

articles.headline: Trump Budget Cuts Put Struggling Americans on Edge
articles.snippet: As news of Mr. Trump’s budget begins to sink in, some Americans feel as if their country no longer has a place for them.
articles.abstract: As news of Mr. Trump’s budget begins to sink in, some Americans feel as if their country no longer has a place for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regina Feltner, a retired nurse, was recovering from side effects of radiation therapy when she got the notice that her heat would be cut off. It was a bone-cold January day. The snow was so high that her daughter had to come over to take the dog out.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, a Voice of Caution Guides a High-Flying Uber
articles.snippet: The venture capitalist Bill Gurley is a rare figure in Silicon Valley, vocally chiding some of the biggest start-up stars to show some discipline.
articles.abstract: The venture capitalist Bill Gurley is a rare figure in Silicon Valley, vocally chiding some of the biggest start-up stars to show some discipline.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Travis Kalanick, the famously combative chief executive of Uber, took the stage at a Vanity Fair conference in San Francisco last October and quickly faced a prickly question. Why all the blunders at the company, Vanity Fair’s editor, Graydon Carter, asked. And had Mr. Kalanick learned anything?

articles.headline: A Small Table Maker Takes On Alibaba’s Flood of Fakes
articles.snippet: With his computer and simple software, Greg Hankerson hunts for counterfeits and seeks other small businesses willing to fight a Chinese e-commerce giant.
articles.abstract: With his computer and simple software, Greg Hankerson hunts for counterfeits and seeks other small businesses willing to fight a Chinese e-commerce giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — From his desk in a downtown workshop, Greg Hankerson is at war with a Chinese company half a world away.

articles.headline: Gripes About Obamacare Aside, Health Insurers Are in a Profit Spiral
articles.snippet: Even in a supercharged stock market, UnitedHealth and its peers are outperforming the market. The reasons may surprise you.
articles.abstract: Even in a supercharged stock market, UnitedHealth and its peers are outperforming the market. The reasons may surprise you.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, big managed care companies like UnitedHealth Group have contributed to the furor over the fate of the Affordable Care Act by saying that important parts of it are fundamentally flawed.

articles.headline: Beneath Mask of Normal Nigerian Life, Young Lives Scarred by Boko Haram
articles.snippet: In Maiduguri, former fighters and child captives blend into the urban tapestry, a place where nearly everyone has been a victim, a collaborator — or both.
articles.abstract: In Maiduguri, former fighters and child captives blend into the urban tapestry, a place where nearly everyone has been a victim, a collaborator — or both.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — She hears the awful sounds in her dreams. They are the moans of a dying girl.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson

articles.headline: In Gorsuch, Conservative Activist Sees Test Case for Reshaping the Judiciary
articles.snippet: As President Trump fills 124 judgeships, Leonard A. Leo is at the center of an influential group of conservatives seeking to transform the bench.
articles.abstract: As President Trump fills 124 judgeships, Leonard A. Leo is at the center of an influential group of conservatives seeking to transform the bench.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Deep into the Senate’s 68-page questionnaire of Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, the Supreme Court nominee was asked to describe how he had come to President Trump’s attention.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Jimmy Breslin, Legendary New York City Newspaper Columnist, Dies at 88
articles.snippet: With prose that was savagely funny, deceptively simple and poorly imitated, Mr. Breslin created his own distinct rhythm in the hurly-burly music of newspapers.
articles.abstract: With prose that was savagely funny, deceptively simple and poorly imitated, Mr. Breslin created his own distinct rhythm in the hurly-burly music of newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jimmy Breslin, the New York City newspaper columnist and best-selling author who leveled the powerful and elevated the powerless for more than 50 years with brick-hard words and a jagged-glass wit, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 and, until very recently, was still pushing somebody’s buttons with two-finger jabs at his keyboard.

articles.headline: Using Special Forces Against Terrorism, Trump Seeks to Avoid Big Ground Wars
articles.snippet: President Trump has so far maintained the strategy of training and supporting indigenous forces to fight their own wars instead of deploying large American forces to far-flung hot spots.
articles.abstract: President Trump has so far maintained the strategy of training and supporting indigenous forces to fight their own wars instead of deploying large American forces to far-flung hot spots.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARA, Chad — From Yemen to Syria to here in Central Africa, the Trump administration is relying on Special Operations forces to intensify its promised fight against the Islamic State and other terrorist groups as senior officials embrace an Obama-era strategy to minimize the American military’s footprint overseas.

articles.headline: Choice of I.M.F. Critic Highlights Trump’s Reversal of Global Policy
articles.snippet: Adam Lerrick, set to be nominated as deputy under secretary of the Treasury for international finance, has been a vocal scold of global bodies like the International Monetary Fund for nearly 20 years.
articles.abstract: Adam Lerrick, set to be nominated as deputy under secretary of the Treasury for international finance, has been a vocal scold of global bodies like the International Monetary Fund for nearly 20 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly 20 years, Adam Lerrick, a conservative economist, has been a vocal scold of global organizations like the International Monetary Fund, arguing that such institutions burn through taxpayer money and foster an insular culture of elitism, bailouts and scant accountability.

articles.headline: A.I. Is Doing Legal Work. But It Won’t Replace Lawyers, Yet.
articles.snippet: The legal profession relies more and more on automation. But fears that it will be automated out of existence are overblown, researchers say. For now.
articles.abstract: The legal profession relies more and more on automation. But fears that it will be automated out of existence are overblown, researchers say. For now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Impressive advances in artificial intelligence technology tailored for legal work have led some lawyers to worry that their profession may be Silicon Valley’s next victim.

articles.headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Ads Work Around Glaring Absence: Players
articles.snippet: Companies spend more than $1 billion on TV ads tied to the men’s basketball tournament, but none of them can use the names or likenesses of the athletes.
articles.abstract: Companies spend more than $1 billion on TV ads tied to the men’s basketball tournament, but none of them can use the names or likenesses of the athletes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament is about last-second shots, bracket-busting upsets and the kind of excitement that can energize college campuses for weeks. It is also a case study in what sports marketing looks like when the athletes are off limits.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Titan’s Surefire Bet Turns Into a $4 Billion Loss
articles.snippet: William A. Ackman was on his way to being a legend of Wall Street — until one of his biggest wagers went very wrong.
articles.abstract: William A. Ackman was on his way to being a legend of Wall Street — until one of his biggest wagers went very wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little over two years ago, William A. Ackman, one of Wall Street’s brashest and most self-assured hedge fund managers, was on top of the world. A billionaire before he hit 50, he was generating double-digit gains for his investors and raking in hundreds of millions in fees for his firm and himself.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Trump’s Wiretap Accusations Renew Debate About Privacy
articles.snippet: After the president’s latest attack on American intelligence agencies, questions resurfaced on whether they invade privacy and could undermine democracy.
articles.abstract: After the president’s latest attack on American intelligence agencies, questions resurfaced on whether they invade privacy and could undermine democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing beside Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday at the White House, President Trump told her, “at least we have something in common.”

articles.headline: A ‘Dying Breed’ Taking More Than Its Loud, Local Voice With It
articles.snippet: The columnist Jimmy Breslin’s death pushes a worrisome trend into view: As news organizations chase broader readership, they risk losing a local focus.
articles.abstract: The columnist Jimmy Breslin’s death pushes a worrisome trend into view: As news organizations chase broader readership, they risk losing a local focus.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reason I fell in love with newspapers — the printed kind — was because of the great columnists of the New York City tabloids, whose bylines hit the sidewalks like anvils when the delivery trucks dropped their bundled papers off at newsstands overnight.

articles.headline: Trump Shifting Authority Over Military Operations Back to Pentagon
articles.snippet: The change reverses what aides say was the Obama administration’s tendency to micromanage, but it could raise questions of whether the president is exercising enough oversight.
articles.abstract: The change reverses what aides say was the Obama administration’s tendency to micromanage, but it could raise questions of whether the president is exercising enough oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is shifting more authority over military operations to the Pentagon, according to White House officials, reversing what his aides and some generals say was a tendency by the Obama White House to micromanage issues better left to military commanders.

articles.headline: In Battle for Digital India, Vodafone Teams Up With Idea Cellular
articles.snippet: The $23 billion deal would create one of the world’s largest cellphone providers, with roughly 400 million subscribers in the country.
articles.abstract: The $23 billion deal would create one of the world’s largest cellphone providers, with roughly 400 million subscribers in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: India is fast becoming the new battleground for global technology and telecommunications giants, as Facebook, Vodafone and others vie to connect the country’s population of 1.2 billion to the internet.

articles.headline: China’s Taxes on Imported Cars Feed Trade Tensions With U.S.
articles.snippet: Autos are emerging as a potential point of contention ahead of President Trump’s meeting with his Chinese counterpart, but the industry sees no easy answers.
articles.abstract: Autos are emerging as a potential point of contention ahead of President Trump’s meeting with his Chinese counterpart, but the industry sees no easy answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Jeep Wrangler can cost $30,000 more in China than in the United States — and the reasons illustrate a growing point of tension between the two countries.

articles.headline: David Rockefeller, Philanthropist and Head of Chase Manhattan, Dies at 101
articles.snippet: Mr. Rockefeller was influential in foreign affairs, helped resolve New York’s fiscal crisis in the 1970s and was chairman of the Museum of Modern Art for many years.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rockefeller was influential in foreign affairs, helped resolve New York’s fiscal crisis in the 1970s and was chairman of the Museum of Modern Art for many years.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Rockefeller, the banker and philanthropist with the fabled family name who controlled Chase Manhattan bank for more than a decade and wielded vast influence around the world for even longer as he spread the gospel of American capitalism, died on Monday morning at his home in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. He was 101.
